name: Stroke

toc.text: Early Decompressive Surgery in Malignant Infarction
Moya Moya Differential and Work-up Considerations

html:
Stroke Alerts

STROKE ALERT Inclusion Criteria

  • Age >1 month
  • Focal neurologic deficits with duration <24h (unilateral weakness or numbness, aphasia, ataxia, visual field cut)

Appropriate Workup/Procedures

EPIC Orderset

Parameters

Normothermia: treat >38.3¬∞C with acetaminophen

Normotensive: Notify neurology if SBP <50th or >95th percentile for age

Normal O2: >90% SpO2

Normovolemia: use normal saline (avoid IVF until intracranial mass ruled out)

Establish IV access and make patient NPO

HOB Flat. If signs of increased ICP, elevate bed to 30 degrees and order STAT Head CT

Studies

EKG, Chest X-ray

Labs

CBC, CMP, DIC Panel, LFTs, ESR, CRP, Utox, +/- B-HCG, +/- specialized testing for patients on anticoag

If patient with sickle cell disease: add Type & Cross, Hg electrophoresis, blood cultures if febrile

Imaging

CTH if MRI not immediately available. Then MRI BRAIN STROKE ALERT EMERGENT (perform ASAP). In certain circumstances, CT/CTA may be obtained alternatively. If patient not within time window for intervention or excluded for other reasons, consider ordering ‚ÄúMRI Stroke or TIA Urgent, perform within 24 hours.‚Äù

Other

Consider blood cultures and antibiotics if febrile. If Sickle Cell Disease, start abx after obtaining cx

SPECIAL tPA CONSIDERATIONS

Cases with >1/3 of cerebral hemisphere affected on imaging

tPA is excluded with CT hypodensity >1/3 of cerebral hemisphere

There are no guidelines for IV tPA use when MRI has >1/3 of cerebral hemisphere w/cytotoxic edema

Intracranial neoplasm

Typically would not give tPA

Intracranial hemorrhage

Typically would not give tPA

Aortic arch dissections

Typically would not give tPA (extracranial dissections are not a contraindication)

WAKEUP stroke symptoms: MRI within 4.5 hours of symptom recognition, with DWI lesions in <1/3 of MCA territory and no FLAIR changes

Could consider IV tPA. Do not delay thrombectomy to give tPA.

Sickle Cell Disease

Do not give tPA

TPA Form

INDICATIONS TO consider TPA (All need to be YES):

Yes

No

Is patient 2 years or older?

Is clinical presentation consistent with an ischemic stroke corresponding to an arterial vascular territory?

Does the patient have a significant neurological deficit as defined as PedsNIHSS >6, or a life altering deficit?

Can IV tPA be given within 4.5 hours of last known normal?

Is there radiographically confirmed ischemic stroke by either:

a) MRI confirmation with restricted diffusion in vascular territory, with or without occlusion of intracranial artery?

  • CT head that is normal or early area of hypodensity in vascular territory, with or without an occlusion of intracranial artery?

Is it confirmed there is NO intracranial hemorrhage?

CONTRAINDICATIONS TO TPA (All need to be NO):

Yes

No

Does the patient have persistent systolic blood pressure > 15% above the 95thpercentile for age and height?

Does the patient have symptoms consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage?

Does patient have known bleeding diathesis or underlying bleeding disorder? (Platelets <100,000, INR > 1.7, PT>15s)

Has patient taken low molecular weight heparin/lovenox within 24 hours or direct oral anti-coagulation within 48 hours?

Has patient had prior intracranial hemorrhage, including from vascular malformation?

Has patient had active internal bleeding within 21 days or any GI/GU bleeding from malignancy?

Has patient had major surgery/trauma (not head) within 14 days?

Has patient had surgery/arterial puncture at non-compressible site in last 7 days?

Has patient had brain or spine surgery in last 3 months?

Has patient had severe head trauma or major trauma within 3 months?

Does patient have an unruptured aneurysm >10mm?

Does patient have intracranial neoplasm?

Does patient have symptoms of infective endocarditis?

Does patient have an aortic arch dissection?

Has the patient had a stroke in the last month?

Is patient pregnant?

In certain clinical situations IV tPA may be given outside of these guidelines

In certain clinical situations IV tPA may not be given when meeting these guidelines

Intra-arterial Therapy Checklist

Considerations for Pediatric Patients <6 hours from symptom onset

Patient meets criteria for possible thrombectomy if yes to all the following:

YES

NO

Patient > 3 years of age?+

Able to perform groin puncture prior to last known normal of 6 hours?*

Little to no pre-stroke disability?*

NIHSS > 6?*

Occlusion of ICA or M1 on MRA?*

MRI ASPECTS Score > 6* or < 1/3rd MCA?+

Does patient meet criteria for IV tPA?

If yes, may consider IV tPA first. Treatment does not influence thrombectomy decision*

If all of the above criteria are met, the child meets all of the current AHA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines 2018 for thrombectomy in adults (*)

Cases where criteria for consideration of thrombectomy has less evidence for safety and/or efficacy, but could be considered in certain situations

YES

NO

Moderate pre-stroke disability?*

Occlusion of M2?*

Occlusion in Posterior Circulation?*

NIHSS < 6?*

Patient <3 years of age+

If any of the above criteria are met, the child meets a lower level of evidence of thrombectomy in adults within 6 hours (AHA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines 2018 level 2B evidence) (*)

Considerations for Pediatric Patients 6-24 hours from symptom onset

Patient meets criteria for possible thrombectomy if yes to all the following:

YES

NO

Patient > 3 years of age?+

Last known normal between 6-24 hours ago?*

Little to no pre-stroke disability (mRS 0-1)?*

Occlusion of ICA or M1 on imaging? *

Patient must have a mismatch between severity of clinical deficit and infarct volume as defined as either 1 OR 2:

1. NIHSS 10-19?

-AND-

Infarct volume < 31ml using DWI?*

2. NIHSS > 20?

-AND-

Infarct volume of < 51 ml using DWI?*

Able to perform groin puncture prior to last known normal of 24 hours?*

If all of the above criteria are met, the child meets all of the current AHA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines 2018 for thrombectomy in adults (*)

Malignant Infarctions

Early Decompressive Surgery in Malignant Infarction

  • Large Infarct Volume (e.g. greater than 50% of MCA) territory [as determined by neuroradiology, neurosurgery and neurology] on presenting CT or MRI.
  • Age > 1 year.
  • Timepoint < 48 hours from last known normal.

If patient meets these criteria, the patient should be admitted to the PICU (or CICU).  The neurosurgical team should decide upon either: 1) early decompressive surgery in first 24 hours, or 2) close monitoring.  Close monitoring should include:

  • Scheduled fast-sequence MRI (or CT scans if MRI unfeasible or unavailable) x 48 hours as permitted by clinical condition (Suggested: Q8-12 hours for 24 hours from stroke onset, then 36 hours and 48 hours from stroke), unless clinical condition is too tenuous for travel.
  • Q1 hour neuro checks.

If close monitoring reveals a significant clinical or radiographic change, a conversation involving the stroke team, neurosurgery, and critical care is encouraged; decompression should be considered.

  • ‚â•8 mm of midline shift on imaging (overall).
  • Progression of midline shift of ‚â•2 mm as compared to prior scan.
  • Development of hemorrhagic transformation and/or increase in hemorrhagic transformation compared with any previous CT/MRI scan.
  • Significant change in mental status.
  • Anisocoria.

Desired Outcome: Decreased prevalence of patients progressing to clinical herniation as defined as blown pupil, and improved 3-month outcome on PSOM (Pediatric Stroke Outcome Measure) as compared to historical controls.

Pediatric NIHSS

(Also available on MDCalc)

Ischemic Stroke Ddx and Workup

Stroke mimics

Seizure with Todd‚Äôs paralysis, hemiplegic migraine, Bell‚Äôs palsy, Alternating hemiplegia of childhood, Brain tumor, CNS infection (meningitis/encephalitis/abscess), posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), demyelinating disease (MS, ADEM, transverse myelitis, NMO, anti-MOG, ADIP), SOD, CMTX, Idiopathic intracranial hypertension, acute cerebellar ataxia

Ischemic Stroke DDx & Associated Workup

Specific diagnoses

Testing to Consider

Cardiac (cardioembolic and hypoperfusion)

Congenital heart disease, endocarditis

Echo w/bubble, EKG

Arteriopathy, Hemoglobinopathy

Focal cerebral arteriopathy, Moya Moya, Sickle cell

+/- conventional angiogram, HSV and VZV PCR/IgG/IgM in serum and CSF, ESR, CRP

Infection

Meningitis (esp tuberculosis, pneumococcal)

Basic CSF studies

Hypercoagulability

-Consider for CSVT, embolic ischemic stroke, term infants with IVH

-Perform tests at 6 mo age

Protein C deficiency, Protein S deficiency, antithrombin deficiency, lipoprotein (a) elevation, plasminogen activator inhibitor polymorphism, MTHFR mutation, Factor V Leiden, malignancy, dehydration, sepsis

Hematology Consult

Protein C activity, Protein S antigen, Anti-thrombin III, Factor VIII activity, Fibrinogen, Lipoprotein (a), Homocysteine, Prothombin mutation G20210A, Factor V Leiden mutation, MFTHR Mutation, Lupus anticoagulant (DVVT), Anti-cardiolipin ab IgG, IgM, IgA, Anti-beta-2-glycoprotein Ab IgG, IgM, IgA, CBC, ESR, CRP, APL AB

Inflammatory/Infectious Vasculitis

childhood primary angiitis of the central nervous system (cPACNS), SLE, DADA2, polyarteritis nodosa, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Takayasu, rheumatologic NOS, HIV, syphilis

Labs: CRP, ESR, ANA, rheumatoid factor, hepatitis panel, RPR, dsDNA

  • CSF: VZV + HSV PCR, VZV IgM and IgG Abs, VDRL, HIV
  • 2nd line: SPEP, UPEP, p-ANCA, c-ANCA, C3, C4, homocyteinuria
  • Genetics: mutations in CECR1 gene (DADA2), and/or plasma ADA2 activity

Imaging: Consider vessel wall imaging, catheter angiogram, brain biopsy

Metabolic, genetic

MELAS, POLG

Serum/CSF lactate, molecular genetic testing

Connective Tissue Disorders/Genetic Vascular

EDS IV, Loeys Dietz, Fabry, PHACE syndrome, Alagille

Consider targeted genetic testing pending clinical concern

EDS IV: COL3A1, LDS: TGFBR1, TGFBR2, SMAD3

Compression/Trauma

Dissection 2/2 trauma, herniation syndromes

Consider dynamic conventional angiogram w/head rotation, neurosurgical eval

Posterior Circulation

Dissection, Rotational Vertebral Artery Syndrome (Bow Hunter), herniation syndromes

Consider dynamic conventional angiogram w/head rotation, neurosurgical eval

Additional Details :

Ferriero DM, Fullerton HJ, Bernard TJ, et al. Management of stroke in neonates and children: a scientific statement from the American heart association/American stroke association. Stroke. 2019;50(3).

Link: Management of Stroke in Neonates and Children

Moya Moya Differential and Work-up Considerations

Differential: Alagille Syndrome, Down Syndrome, microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism, neurofibromatosis type 1, PHACE syndrome, Robinow syndrome, Seckel syndrome, sickle cell disease, radiation sequel, tuberous sclerosis, Marfans

Genetic considerations: RNF213, ACTA2, R179, BRCC3/MTCPI, GUCYIA3, SAMHD1

Note: There is a special protocol for anesthesia for Moya Moya kids. If not present

Note: For patients with Moya Moya, TPA is contraindicated, may be thrombectom

y candidate

Hemorrhagic Stroke

Hemorrhagic Stroke  

Differential diagnosis: Vascular malformation (AVM, cavernous hemangioma, aneurysm, venous malformation), brain tumor, trauma/dissection, hematologic dysfunction related to liver disease, sepsis or primary hematologic disorder

Workup: For hemorrhagic strokes w/o vascular malformation, consider checking PT, PTT, Factor XIII, platelet function and consider COL4A1 testing if personal hx congenital cataracts/glaucoma or family hx of congenital cataracts, cerebral palsy or hemorrhagic stroke

Potentially helpful resources to reference:

  • Hunt and Hess grading system: tool to gauge clinical severity and mortality risk related to SAH from rupture of intracerebral aneurysm
  • Modified Fisher scale: Radiological grading of SAH 2/2 intracerebral aneurysm rupture

 Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Grading

Image Source: https://www.childrensmn.org

Neonatal Stroke

Age

Perinatal IVH/periventricular venous infarct

Perinatal CSVT w/wo Stroke

Perinatal arterial ischemic stroke

NICU

No thrombophilia testing unless family history is positive for early DVT, PE, MI or AIS (usually age <50y), unusual in extent/severity, propagating infarct or presence of extra-cranial thrombosis

Refer to Early Intervention

Consider COL4A1 genetic testing if congenital cataracts and/or family history of cerebral palsy, hemorrhagic stroke, early unexplained death

Initiate enoxaparin

ECHO only if multifocal stroke and/or abnormal cardiac exam

2-4 weeks

Consider maternal anti-phospholipid antibody testing

Anti-Xa level, adjust enoxaparin

3 mo

EEG (f dx made <28 DOL)

MRI/MRV w/wo contrast

6 mo

Thrombophilia testing now if have positive family history or extracranial thromboses (non-line-related); check Factor XIII, PAI-1, antiplasmin if isolated IVH or recurrent IVH, hemorrhage with normal PT/PTT

5y

Neuropsych testing

Childhood CSVT

Presentation

Consults: Neuro, Hematology +/- NSGY if substantial bleeding, large clot or possibility for endovascular tx

Anticoagulation per hematology: start w/UFH if high bleed risk, enoxaparin if average bleed risk, with transition to warfarin if preferred. May need multi-disciplinary approach if complex med hx

Direct oral anticoagulant (i.e. rivaroxaban, apixaban) can be considered (if not obese, not triple +APL Ab)

Thombophilia testing w/APLA workup (dRVVT, hexagonal PTT, anticardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein) + hematology recs

If mastoiditis/severe infection, can do just APLA workup. Otherwise, add protein C, protein S, antithrombin, Factor V Leiden, PT20210

Consider optho consult if applicable

2-4 weeks out

Anti-Xa level, adjust enoxaparin

3 mo

MRI/MRV

Discontinue anticoagulation if CSVT provoked, resolved, asymptomatic w/o ongoing risk factors or identified thrombophilia

6 mo

Repeat MRI/MRV if still on anticoagulation

Neuropsych testing

12 mo

Consider repeat MRI/MRV regardless of anticoagulation status

Probably discontinue anticoagulation if still on it

Vascular Anatomy

Pediatric LVO Escalation Pathway

Emergency escalation protocol for suspected pediatric large vessel occlusion requiring endovascular intervention. On-call emergency reference ‚Äî act quickly and call multiple hospitals simultaneously if needed.

Step 1 ‚Äî Call Anesthesia

  • Age <12 years: Call Peds anesthesia ‚Äî ask if they have availability/can go to NCMC
  • Age >12 years: Call adult anesthesia at NCMC ‚Äî ask if they would take patient
  • If yes ‚Üí Call endovascular neurosurgery
  • If no ‚Üí Proceed to Step 2 (outside hospitals)

Step 2 ‚Äî Outside Hospitals Transfer Center ‚Äî Call Multiple
